template.template: Template App MS SQL Multi Instance
template.name: Template App MS SQL Multi Instance

item.name: Replication Warning: Transactional replication latency (Threshold: latency)
SQL Default Instance: Number Failed Jobs
SQLServer:Access Methods Forwarded Records/sec
item.description: Rows with varchar columns can experience expansion when varchar values are updated with a longer string. In the case where the row cannot fit in the existing page, the row migrates and access to the row will traverse a pointer. This only happens on heaps (tables without clustered indexes). Evaluate clustered index for heap tables. In cases where clustered indexes cannot be used, drop non-clustered indexes, build a clustered index to reorg pages and rows, drop the clustered index, then recreate non-clustered indexes.

item.name: SQL Server:Access Methods Full Scans/sec
item.description: This counter monitors the number of full scans on base tables or indexes. Values greater than 1 or 2 indicate that we are having table / Index page scans. If we see high CPU then we need to investigate this counter, otherwise if the full scans are on small tables we can ignore this counter. A few of the main causes of high Full Scans/sec are • Missing indexes • Too many rows requested Queries with missing indexes or too many rows requested will have a large number of logical reads and an increased CPU time.

item.name: SQLServer:Access Methods Index Searches/sec
item.description: Number of index searches. Index searches are used to start range scans, single index record fetches, and to reposition within an index. Index searches are preferable to index and table scans. For OLTP applications, optimize for more index searches and less scans (preferably, 1 full scan for every 1000 index searches). Index and table scans are expensive I/O operations.

item.name: SQL Server:Access Methods Page Splits/sec
item.description:
Number of page splits per second that occur as the result of overflowing index pages. Interesting counter that can lead us to our table / index design. This value needs to be low as possible. If you find out that the number of page splits is high, consider increasing the fillfactor of your indexes. An increased fill factor helps to reduce page splits because there is more room in data pages before it fills up and a page split has to occur.
Note that this counter also includes the new page allocations as well and doesn’t necessarily pose a problem. The other place we can confirm the page splits that involve data or index rows moves are the fragmented indexes on page splits.

item.name: SQL Server:Access Methods - Table Lock Escalations/sec
SQL Server:Buffer Manager Buffer Cache hit ratio
item.description: This counter indicates how often SQL Server goes to the buffer, not the hard disk, to get data. The higher this ratio, the less often SQL Server has to go to the hard disk to fetch data, and performance overall is boosted. Unlike many of the other counters available for monitoring SQL Server, this counter averages the Buffer Cache Hit Ratio from the time the last instance of SQL Server was restarted. In other words, this counter is not a real-time measurement, but an average of all the days since SQL Server was last restarted. In OLTP applications, this ratio should exceed 90-95%. If it doesn't, then you need to add more RAM to your server to increase performance. In OLAP applications, the ratio could be much less because of the nature of how OLAP works. In any case, more RAM should increase the performance of SQL Server OLAP activity.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Free list stalls/sec
item.description: Free list stalls/sec is the frequency with which requests for available database pages are suspended because no buffers are available. Free list stall rates of 3 or 4 per second indicate too little SQL memory available.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Lazy Writes/Sec
item.description: This counter tracks how many times a second that the Lazy Writer process is moving dirty pages from the buffer to disk in order to free up buffer space. Generally speaking, this should not be a high value, say more than 20 per second or so. Ideally, it should be close to zero. If it is zero, this indicates that your SQL Server's buffer cache is plenty big and SQL Server doesn't have to free up dirty pages, instead waiting for this to occur during regular checkpoints. If this value is high, then a need for more memory is indicated.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page Life Expectancy
item.description: This performance monitor counter tells you, on average, how long data pages are staying in the buffer. If this value gets below 300 seconds, this is a potential indication that your SQL Server could use more memory in order to boost performance.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page lookups/sec
item.description: Number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool. When the ratio of page lookups to batch requests is much greater than 100, this is an indication that while query plans are looking up data in the buffer pool, these plans are inefficient. Identify queries with the highest amount of logical I/O's and tune them.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page reads/sec
item.description: Number of physical database page reads issued. 80 – 90 per second is normal, anything that is above indicates indexing or memory constraint.

item.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page writes/sec
item.description: Number of physical database page writes issued. 80 – 90 per second is normal, anything more we need to check the lazy writer/sec and checkpoint counters, if these counters are also relatively high then, it’s memory constraint.

item.name: SQLServer:Databases Log Flushes/sec
item.description: Number of Log Flushes.

item.name: SQLServer:Databases Transactions/sec
item.description: Number of Transactions.

item.name: SQL Server:General Statistics Logins/sec
item.description: > 2 per second indicates that the application is not correctly using connection pooling.

item.name: SQL Server:General Statistics Logouts/sec
item.description: > 2 per second indicates that the application is not correctly using connection pooling.

item.name: SQL Server:General Statistics User Connections
item.description:
The number of users currently connected to the SQL Server.
Note: It is recommended to review this counter along with “Batch Requests/Sec”. A surge in “user connections” may result in a surge of “Batch Requests/Sec”. So if there is a disparity (one going up and the other staying flat or going down), then that may be a cause for concern. With a blocking problem, for example, you might see user connections, lock waits and lock wait time all increase while batch requests/sec decreases.

item.name: SQL Server:Latches Latch Waits/sec
item.description: This is the number of latch requests that could not be granted immediately. In other words, these are the amount of latches, in a one second period that had to wait.

item.name: SQL Server:Latches Total Latch Wait Time (ms)
item.description: This is the total latch wait time (in milliseconds) for latch requests in the last second

item.name: SQL Server:Locks Lock Waits/sec
item.description: This counter reports how many times users waited to acquire a lock over the past second. Note that while you are actually waiting on the lock that this is not reflected in this counter—it gets incremented only when you “wake up” after waiting on the lock. If this value is nonzero then it is an indication that there is at least some level of blocking occurring. If you combine this with the Lock Wait Time counter, you can get some idea of how long the blocking lasted. A zero value for this counter can definitively prove out blocking as a potential cause; a nonzero value will require looking at other information to determine whether it is significant.

item.name: SQL Server:Locks Lock Wait Time (ms)
item.description:
Total wait time (milliseconds) for locks in the last second.
Note: For “Lock Wait Time” it is recommended to look beyond the Avg value. Look for any peaks that are close (or exceeds) to a wait of 60 sec. Though this counter counts how many total milliseconds SQL Server is waiting on locks during the last second, but the counter actually records at the end of locking event. So most probably the peaks represent one huge locking event. If those events exceeds more than 60seconds then they may have extended blocking and could be an issue. In such cases, thoroughly analyze the blocking script output. Some applications are written for timing out after 60 seconds and that’s not acceptable response for those applications.

item.name: SQL Server:Locks Number of Deadlocks/sec
item.description: The number of lock requests that resulted in a deadlock.

item.name: SQL Server:Memory Manager Total Server Memory (KB)
item.description: The Total Server Memory is the current amount of memory that SQL Server is using. If this counter is still growing the server has not yet reached its steady-state, and it is still trying to populate the cache and get pages loaded into memory. Performance will likely be somewhat slower during this time since more disk I/O is required at this stage. This behavior is normal. Eventually Total Server Memory should approximate Target Server Memory.

item.name: SQLServer:SQL Statistics Batch Requests/Sec
item.description:
This counter measures the number of batch requests that SQL Server receives per second, and generally follows in step to how busy your server's CPUs are. Generally speaking, over 1000 batch requests per second indicates a very busy SQL Server, and could mean that if you are not already experiencing a CPU bottleneck, that you may very well soon. Of course, this is a relative number, and the bigger your hardware, the more batch requests per second SQL Server can handle. From a network bottleneck approach, a typical 100Mbs network card is only able to handle about 3000 batch requests per second. If you have a server that is this busy, you may need to have two or more network cards, or go to a 1Gbs network card.
Note: Sometimes low batch requests/sec can be misleading. If there were a SQL statements/sec counter, this would be a more accurate measure of the amount of SQL Server activity. For example, an application may call only a few stored procedures yet each stored procedure does lot of work. In that case, we will see a low number for batch requests/sec but each stored procedure (one batch) will execute many SQL statements that drive CPU and other resources. As a result, many counter thresholds based on the number of batch requests/sec will seem to identify issues because the batch requests on such a server are unusually low for the level of activity on the server.
We cannot conclude that a SQL Server is not active simply by looking at only batch requests/sec. Rather, you have to do more investigation before deciding there is no load on the server. If the average number of batch requests/sec is below 5 and other counters (such as SQL Server processor utilization) confirm the absence of significant activity, then there is not enough of a load to make any recommendations or identify issues regarding scalability.

item.name: SQLServer:SQL Statistics SQL Compilations/sec
item.description: The number of times per second that SQL Server compilations have occurred. This value needs to be as low as possible. If you see a high value such as over 100, then it’s an indication that there are lots of adhoc queries that are running, might cause CPU usage, solution is to re-write these adhoc as stored procedure or use sp_executeSQL.

item.name: SQLServer:SQL Statistics SQL Re-Compilations/sec
item.description: This needs to be zero as much as possible. A recompile can cause deadlocks and compile locks that are not compatible with any locking type.

discovery_rule.name: MS SQL DB Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovers databases within the default instance using a Powershell script.

item_prototype.name: SQLServer {$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS}) Active Transactions
item_prototype.description: Number of active transactions for the database.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS})\Log Flush Wait Time",300].last()}>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQLServer {$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS}) Log Flush Wait Time

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS})\Log Flush Waits/sec",300].last()}>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQLServer {$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS})\Log Flush Waits/sec

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS})\Percent Log Used",300].last()}>80
trigger_prototype.name: SQLServer {$SQLINST1}:Databases({#DBS})\Percent Log Used

resource.name: SQLServer:Databases({#DBS}) Transactions
resource.host: Template App MS SQL Multi Instance

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:net.tcp.listen[{$MSSQLPORT}].last(,0)}=0
trigger.name: SQL Port

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Access Methods\Forwarded Records/sec",300].last()}>0.1*{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec",300].last()}
trigger.name: SQLServer:Access Methods Forwarded Records/sec

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Access Methods\Index Searches/sec",300].last()}/{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Access Methods\Full Scans/sec",300].last()}>1000
trigger.name: SQLServer:Access Methods Full Scans / sec
trigger.description: This counter monitors the number of full scans on base tables or indexes. Values greater than 1 or 2 indicate that we are having table / Index page scans. If we see high CPU then we need to investigate this counter, otherwise if the full scans are on small tables we can ignore this counter. A few of the main causes of high Full Scans/sec are • Missing indexes • Too many rows requested Queries with missing indexes or too many rows requested will have a large number of logical reads and an increased CPU time.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Access Methods\Page Splits/sec",300].last()}>0.2*{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec",300].last()}
trigger.name: SQLServer:Access Methods Page Splits/sec
trigger.description:
Number of page splits per second that occur as the result of overflowing index pages. Interesting counter that can lead us to our table / index design. This value needs to be low as possible. If you find out that the number of page splits is high, consider increasing the fillfactor of your indexes. An increased fillfactor helps to reduce page splits because there is more room in data pages before it fills up and a page split has to occur.
Note that this counter also includes the new page allocations as well and doesn’t necessarily pose a problem. The other place we can confirm the page splits that involve data or index rows moves are the fragmented indexes on page splits.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Buffer cache hit ratio",300].last(,0)}<90
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Buffer Cache hit ratio
trigger.description: This counter indicates how often SQL Server goes to the buffer, not the hard disk, to get data. The higher this ratio, the less often SQL Server has to go to the hard disk to fetch data, and performance overall is boosted. Unlike many of the other counters available for monitoring SQL Server, this counter averages the Buffer Cache Hit Ratio from the time the last instance of SQL Server was restarted. In other words, this counter is not a real-time measurement, but an average of all the days since SQL Server was last restarted. In OLTP applications, this ratio should exceed 90-95%. If it doesn't, then you need to add more RAM to your server to increase performance. In OLAP applications, the ratio could be much less because of the nature of how OLAP works. In any case, more RAM should increase the performance of SQL Server OLAP activity.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Free list stalls/sec",300].last(,0)}>3
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Free list stalls/sec
trigger.description: Free list stalls/sec is the frequency with which requests for available database pages are suspended because no buffers are available. Free list stall rates of 3 or 4 per second indicate too little SQL memory available.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Lazy Writes/Sec",300].last(,0)}>20
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Lazy Writes/Sec

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Page Life Expectancy",300].last(,0)}<300
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page Life Expectancy

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Page lookups/sec",300].last()}/{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec",300].last()}>100
trigger.name: SQLServer:Buffer Manager Page lookups/sec
trigger.description: Number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool. When the ratio of page lookups to batch requests is much greater than 100, this is an indication that while query plans are looking up data in the buffer pool, these plans are inefficient. Identify queries with the highest amount of logical I/O's and tune them.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Page reads/sec",300].last(,0)}>90
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page reads/sec
trigger.description: Number of physical database page reads issued. 80 – 90 per second is normal, anything that is above indicates indexing or memory constraint.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Buffer Manager\Page writes/sec",300].last(,0)}>90
trigger.name: SQL Server:Buffer Manager Page writes/sec
trigger.description: Number of physical database page writes issued. 80 – 90 per second is normal, anything that is above indicates indexing or memory constraint.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:General Statistics\Logins/sec",300].last(,0)}>2
trigger.name: SQLServer:General Statistics Logins/sec
trigger.description: > 2 per second indicates that the application is not correctly using connection pooling.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:General Statistics\Logouts/sec",300].last(,0)}>2
trigger.name: SQLServer:General Statistics Logouts/sec
trigger.description: > 2 per second indicates that the application is not correctly using connection pooling.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Latches\Total Latch Wait Time (ms)",300].last()}/{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Latches\Latch Waits/sec",300].last()}>10
trigger.name: SQL Server:Latches Latch Waits/sec

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Waits/sec",300].last(,0)}>10
trigger.name: SQL Server:Locks Lock Waits/sec
trigger.description: This counter reports how many times users waited to acquire a lock over the past second. Note that while you are actually waiting on the lock that this is not reflected in this counter—it gets incremented only when you “wake up” after waiting on the lock. If this value is nonzero then it is an indication that there is at least some level of blocking occurring. If you combine this with the Lock Wait Time counter, you can get some idea of how long the blocking lasted. A zero value for this counter can definitively prove out blocking as a potential cause; a nonzero value will require looking at other information to determine whether it is significant.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Wait Time (ms)",300].last(,0)}>1000
trigger.name: SQL Server:Locks Lock Wait Time (ms)
trigger.description:
Total wait time (milliseconds) for locks in the last second.
Note: For “Lock Wait Time” it is recommended to look beyond the Avg value. Look for any peaks that are close (or exceeds) to a wait of 60 sec. Though this counter counts how many total milliseconds SQL Server is waiting on locks during the last second, but the counter actually records at the end of locking event. So most probably the peaks represent one huge locking event. If those events exceeds more than 60seconds then they may have extended blocking and could be an issue. In such cases, thoroughly analyze the blocking script output. Some applications are written for timing out after 60 seconds and that’s not acceptable response for those applications.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:Locks(_Total)\Number of Deadlocks/sec",300].last(,0)}>1
trigger.name: SQL Server:Locks Number of Deadlocks/sec
trigger.description: The number of lock requests that resulted in a deadlock.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\SQL Compilations/sec",300].last()}>0.1*{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec",300].last()}
trigger.name: SQLServer:SQL Statistics SQL Compilations/sec
trigger.description: The number of times per second that SQL Server compilations have occurred. This value needs to be as low as possible. If you see a high value such as over 100, then it’s an indication that there are lots of adhoc queries that are running, might cause CPU usage, solution is to re-write these adhoc as stored procedure or use sp_executeSQL.

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\SQL Re-Compilations/sec",300].last()}>0.1*{Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:perf_counter["\{$SQLINST1}:SQL Statistics\SQL Compilations/sec",300].last()}
trigger.name: SQLServer:SQL Statistics SQL Re-Compilations/sec

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:service_state[{$SQLSRV}].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: SQL Server Service

trigger.expression: {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:eventlog[Application,,"Information",,^14161$].logseverity(0)}>1 and {Template App MS SQL Multi Instance:eventlog[Application,,"Information",,^14161$].nodata(1800)}=0
trigger.name: Transactional replication latency (Threshold: latency)' occurred on {HOST.NAME}
